subject: Re: [junit] How can i test a geter or seter?
msgSnippet: Saturday, December 22, 2001, 4:07:41 AM, evought@qlue.com wrote: evought Simple methods break, too. As posted last time this discussion went around evought
messageBody:
Saturday, December 22, 2001, 4:07:41 AM, evought@... wrote:

evought> Simple methods break, too. As posted last time this discussion went around
evought> the exact same circles:
...
evought> public void setJ(int j) {d_j = j;}
evought> public int getJ() {return d_i;}

evought> This code is trivial. It is also wrong. Somebody probably created the
evought> accessors for i and then cut and paste them for j without editting
evought> everywhere they should. Without a testcase here, there will be a more
evought> complex failure somewhere else. Somebody will spend an hour or so pulling
evought> their hair out. A testcase for this is very quick to do.

The main problem with testing at this level is that, just as it is
tempting to create the getters and setters using cut-n-paste, it is
tempting to create the unit tests using cut-n-paste. Admit it, we've
all done it.

After a lot of soul searching, the conclusion I have come to for my
own work is that unit tests should not really be testing the "raw"
methods of a class. Rather, they should be testing the real
functionality actually required by users of the class.

I can't help help feeling in this case that (maybe) there might
actually be no real need for a getJ() accessor, and it may have been
created from a knee-jerk "must provide all the accessors in case
someone wants to use this class as a JavaBean". If you have a real
need in your system to call such a method, then provide a unit test
when you have that need, but before you do that, consider whether the
real need in the system is for a more specific call, which can be
tested in more depth.
